frameDefinitions: An Entity changes from a Prior_state to a Post_state in a sequence that follows a pre-defined plan, expectation, or model of change.
This frame contains words for types of noise which can be used to characterize verbal communication.
A Speaker communicates a message stating an Item's membership in a Category, i.e., asserts that the Item has the defining characteristics of the Category.
A stretch of linguistic discourse or a Text that a Communicator produces has a Topic that it is about.

A Communicator processes some information (either from textual or real-world/perceptual sources) regarding a State_of_affairs into a concise form (a summary) that contains the essential content in briefer form, and communicates this summary to an Addressee, or records it in a Medium.
This frame contains verbs and nouns that communicate the act of a Speaker to address a Message to some Addressee using language.
frameExamples: Their offensive armament has <t>developed</t> from short range missiles to long-range ballistic weaponry in a relatively short period .
'Don't treat me as a child!' she <t>cried</t> scornfully.
He <t>depicted</t> his involvement as merely peripheral.
Frank has already <t>summarized</t> some of the reactions on his weblog.
I now <t>declare</t> you members of this Society.
listRoleDefinitions: The object that undergoes change.
The time at which the progress occurs.
The location where the Progress occurs.
<fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that delivers the <fen>Message</fen>.
Message has a number of different realizations in this frame, including <ment>that</ment>-clauses, direct quotes, infinitival complements, <ment>for-to</ment> phrases, and NP Objects.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs in PP Complements, usually headed by <ment>about</ment>.
The <fen>Voice</fen> describes the <fex name=''>Speaker'</fex>s utterance or other message-encoded production.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> where the Communication noise event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an event occurs.
The individual that communicates the message concerning the <fen>Category</fen> of an <fen>Item</fen>.
The class of entities with characteristics that match those of the <fen>Item</fen> according to the portrayal of the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The entity that the <fen>Speaker</fen> portrays as belonging to a <fen>Category</fen>.
The piece of text in which a <fen>Speaker</fen> communicates their categorization of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes a characterization of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Speaker</fen> characterizes the <fen>Item</fen>
The <fen>Topic</fen> is what a <fen>Text</fen> is about.
A set of propositions that is coherent in being about a <fen>Topic</fen>
The <fen>Communicator</fen> is the person who has produced a <fen>Text</fen> on a <fen>Topic</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Communicator</fen> produces <fen>Text</fen> on a <fen>Topic</fen>.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> creates and communicates the summary of the Information.
The <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> is summarized by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The textual or other <fen>Medium</fen> through which the <fen>Communicator</fen> summarizes.
The time at which the <fen>Communicator</fen> makes the <fen>Summary</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen> (whether spoken or written).  It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target	</t> word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.  It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is made.
The role specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> takes place.
listRoleExamples: Advances <fex>in marketing techniques</fex> have since rendered it obsolete.
<fex>When</fex> did the X-wing progress beyond the drawing board?
Kim howled <fex>about the unfairness of it all</fex>.
<fex>John's voice</fex> bellowed for her to be quiet.
However, <fex>'A Brief History of Medicine'</fex> characterizes influenza as the most deadly plague, overall.
In his book, <fex>Smithers</fex> discusses cotton production.
Evelyn said <fex>that she was not ready to leave</fex>.
Kim preached to me <fex>over the phone</fex>.
In some remarks <fex>at the National Press Club</fex>, Mr. Keating said he would make a better prime minister tha nMr. Hawke.
